• SUPREME COURT KILLS STUDENT DEBT CASE:
On Monday, the Supreme Court denied Thelma McCoy’s groundbreaking petition to have $350,000 of student loan debt cancelled, a case that could have helped
ease the country’s growing student debt crisis
. McCoy had argued that a series of accidents had left her with diminished job prospects and unable to pay off the debt. In denying McCoy’s petition, the Supreme Court
declined to revisit the overly strict Brunner standard

, the rule that says debt can only be forgiven if the borrower’s financial status is unlikely to improve for a substantial part of the repayment period. If the Supreme Court had agreed with McCoy’s petition for a more lenient “totality of the circumstances” standard, student loan debtors across the country might have found it easier to discharge their student loan debt.
